content: We got to the museum right when it opened at 10am. The museum had an information desk and the gentleman recommended the tour to start. I usually wouldn't do a tour but since the place is huge and we didn't really know where to start we thought we'd try it. All the tour guides were senior citizens and completely fabulous!...
If you only have time for one Smithsonian on your visit, this may be it. It is a classic. They have moved the Enola Gay exhibit to the Udvar-Hazy Center.

This museum is cool because it gives you insight to little pieces of aerospace history. Watched D-day IMAX here which was really good and informative.
Overall a great half day visit. And it is free!
Tip- if you do IMAX, save your ticket. You can see any other IMAX at that or another smithsonian for only $6 after that!

This is a very popular museum to the point where you hav more trouble walking around than at any other museum/monument. It's worth the crowds however, as this museum is entertaining for all. Free tours give lots of info and attractions capture your attention and curiosity. We did it over 2 days to help with crowd alleviation which worked perfectly....

It's fantastic to see this incredible collection from the Apollo era, famous planes from the spirit of St Louis to the newer space tourism aircrafts. The whole family enjoyed it , a highlight of our visit to DC.
This was a really cool visit. There were so many things to see inside. This museum would be great for anyone. Adults or children.

Had a wonderful time here with my 8 and 10 year old sons. The museum was extremely child friendly but also great for adults! We spent a total of 4 1/2 hours here. The display rooms were well set up and the layout was great. Can't believe this museum was free, I would definitely pay an entrance fee. Well worth...

Overall great layout of planes and space modules. Tells the story of 20th century aviation technology with actual airplanes, many hanging from the ceiling.
Buying freeze-dried astronaut ice cream brought back memories of visiting when I was a child.
Next to the zoo, the Air and Space Museum is a sure hit with the entire family.

This Museum on the mall is often confused with the "real" National Air and Space Museum next to the Dulles Airport. It does have some cool stuff, as in the Apollo Program moon lander and space capsule, and the original Wright Flyer.
It is more of a kids interactive place that anything else. Go to the the Dulles National Air...

The joke being that admission is free. That said, even if they HAD charged, it would have been worth it. Great space, amazing displays, unparalleled information and presentation.
It was easy to imagine oneself flying in the early years of commercial aviation, or dogfighting over Europe, or plummeting 60,000 feet to earth in the Apollo 11 command capsule. The combination...
